awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Preparing Urban Milwaukee for Pathways in Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Wisconsin faces increasingly inequitable access to Computer Science (CS) content in schools. Affluent suburban schools add courses, such as CS Principles (CSP), at a record rate. Schools with fewer resources have little or no CS offerings and see meager access diminished as scarce while CS teachers are lured away to industry and the suburbs. Marquette University and The Learning Partnership have already made significant inroads in expanding Wisconsin's CS professional development opportunities for teachers. Prior work over the last five years has provided CS Professional Development to over 1,850 K-5 teachers, reaching over 67,000 school children.  Careful assessment will allow the team to explore deeper questions about how prior CS exposure effects students later in the CS pathway, why execution of CS initiatives are so unevenly effective in different parts of the city, and how to strengthen and expand a pathway in a dynamic urban school system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
In a time of historic enrollments in Computer Science (CS) degrees, Wisconsin faces increasingly inequitable access to CS content in schools. Affluent suburban schools add courses such as CS Principles (CSP) at a record rate. Schools with fewer resources have little or no CS; they see meager access diminished as scarce CS teachers are lured away to industry and the suburbs.

The PUMP-CS Research-Practitioner Partnership (RPP) among Milwaukee Public Schools (MPS), Marquette University (MU) and The Learning Partnership (LP) has planted many vital seeds of CS access in the more than 135 separate schools across MPS. MU and LP are cognizant of the need to bring research-based practices to the RPP while co-conducting research with MPS. MU has been leading the co-design of evidence-based practices with MPS, and LP has been measuring the extent to which these practices lead to their intended outcomes. PUMP-CS is focused on developing a systemic, cohesive, PK-12 CS pathway that can provide high-quality courses and experiences across the breadth of MPS school contexts. This pathway must be robust in a school district with ubiquitous school choice, shrinking enrollment, confounding feeder school relationships, deep socioeconomic inequities, and one of the highest levels of racial segregation in the nation. The PUMP-CS RPP has the diverse knowledge and experience necessary to build the right PK-12 CS Pathway for Milwaukee students.

In five years, the PUMP-CS Project has:
  • Provided Computer Science training for 87 teachers across 19 MPS high schools, including coursework in Exploring Computer Science, AP CS Principles, and AP CS "A".
  • Provided Computer Science training for 105 teachers in grades 6-8 across 64 MPS schools, in curricula including CS Discoveries, and Project GUTS, which integrates CS into middle school science courses.
  • Provided Computer Science training for 515 teachers in grades K-5, across 82 MPS schools with elementary grades, reaching some 16,000 students.

In addition the project has created new curriculum tools that can be shared and used beyond Milwaukee, and has conducted research that deepens our understanding of barriers to broadening participation in computer science learning for both teachers and students in large, urban school settings.

 


Last Modified: 02/06/2025
Modified by: Dennis Brylow

The PUMP-CS Research-Practitioner Partnership (RPP) among Milwaukee Public Schools (MPS), Marquette University (MU) and The Learning Partnership (LP) has planted many vital seeds of CS access in the more than 135 separate schools across MPS. MU and LP are cognizant of the need to bring research-based practices to the RPP while co-conducting research with MPS. Provided Computer Science training for 515 teachers in grades K-5, across 82 MPS schools with elementary grades, reaching some 16,000 students.
